page.title: 04Ardross: Glaick & Loanreoch
page.content:
Glaick: The forestry office and a turn of the century house lie at the bottom of the road to Glaick which is the highest point for miles around. The family came to Glaick in 1927. They have 40 beef cattle and 140 sheep and also grow oats, barley, swedes, turnips and grain. The farmer uses tractors, a plough, harrows, ridgers, cultivator discs, a small bailer, hay turners and turnip sowers. Normal working hours are 7am to 9pm but in the lambing season this can be 6am to 11pm (and even through the night). The family don't have holidays.
Loanreoch: This has a small homestead but is mainly woodland with some livestock. There are a lot of sheep some of which are Moorit sheep. There may also be a few St. Kilda sheep.
